title.narrative: Musharaka: Youth-led community development in the Sahrawi refugee camps

description.narrative:
Detta projekt kommer att tillämpa en så kallad "community driven development approach" där befolkningen i de fem västsahariska flyktinglägren kommer att bilda kommittéer (där minst 50 % är ungdomar och minst 50 % är kvinnor) som kommer att samråda med befolkningen i lägren, myndigheter och andra intressenter för att definiera behov och sedan utforma projekt som möter samhällets behov. Ungefär 15 miljoner kronor kommer att tilldelas dessa sub-projekt och syftet med tillvägagångssättet är att skapa en hög grad av lokalt ägarskap, att åtgärda en del av behoven för förbättrade samhällstjänster i lägren samt ge ungdomar en plattform för att visa att de kan bidra till samhällsutvecklingen. Ett antal utbildningar och workshops för kommittérna kommer även att organiseras som en del av projektet.
Projektet kommer att genomföras av Oxfam Solidarité. Oxfam har arbetat med situationen med västsahariska flyktingar sedan 1975 och är således en av de äldsta humanitära aktörerna i lägren och har med tiden skaffat sig legitimitet och respekt hos flyktingarna och myndigheterna.

This project will apply a community driven development approach where the community in the five Sahrawi refugee camps will form taskforces, with at least 50 % youth and 50 % female representation, that will consult with the community, authorities and other stakeholders to define needs and then design projects that address the community needs. Approximately 15 MSEK will be allocated for these community projects. The intention with the approach is to create a high degree ownership, help address some of the social service needs in the camps and provide an avenue for young people to demonstrate their contribution to community development. A comprehensive training and workshop package will also be provided to the taskforces to enable the implementation of the project.
The project will be implemented by Oxfam Solidarité. Oxfam has been working on the Sahrawi refugee situation since 1975 and is therefore one of the oldest humanitarian actors in the camps and has over time gained legitimacy and respect among the community and authorities.

The contribution will support Oxfam Solidarité to implement their project Musharaka: Youth-led community development in the Sahrawi refugee camps. In the Letter of Appropriation to Sida for 2018 an assignment was included to support the local situation in Western Sahara under the Strategy for Sustainable Peace 2017-2022. The main objective of the project is to improve the role of youth in community development in the Sahrawi refugee camps. The specific objective is to strengthen the capacities and self-confidence of youth, and their recognition as active participants in community development, by the authorities and other stakeholders. Main objective: to improve the role of youth in community development in the Sahrawi refugee camps Specific objective: Strengthening the capacities and self-confidence of youth, and their recognition as active participants in community development, by the authorities and other stakeholders Result 1: The five taskforces, selected through a participative and inclusive process, are functional, and are aware of their responsibility towards the community. Result 2: Community taskforces have completed a cycle of training and improved their technical skills Result 3: Youth, as an important part of the taskforces, have developed and successfully implemented inclusive and sustainable projects that respond to the needs of the community Result 4: Local authorities and taskforces have developed a relationship of trust. Since the community projects under result 3 will be designed during the implementation the results framework will be updated by Oxfam when their focus have been agreed. The updated results framework will be submitted to Sida for approval as stipulated in the agreement.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

tag.narrative: 16.7 - Ensure responsive, inclusive, participatory and representative decision-making at all levels.
16.7 - Säkerställa ett lyhört, inkluderande, deltagandebaserat och representativt beslutsfattande på alla nivåer.

16.a - Strengthen relevant national institutions, including through international cooperation, for building capacity at all levels, in particular in developing countries, to prevent violence and combat terrorism and crime.

16.a - Stärka berörda nationella institutioner, bland annat genom internationellt samarbete, i syfte att bygga upp kapacitet på alla nivåer, i synnerhet i utvecklingsländerna, för att förebygga våld och bekämpa terrorism och brottslighet.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.
5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

title.narrative: Avtal Sida och Oxfam Solidarité för Musharaka projektet i Västsahara, insats 12545
Beslut om insats, Oxfams Musharaka-projekt i Västsahara, insats 12545

description.narrative: The results achieved in the reporting period primarily concern the recruitment and training of taskforce members; drafts of concept notes for different community projects; and trust building between local authorities, taskforces and Oxfam. 50 taskforce members have been recruited and received training in: teamwork; inclusion and vulnerability; active citizenship; communications; and project management. The training sessions have for example enhanced taskforce members awareness of group decision making tools; an understanding of how individual and social elements affect exclusion; and a sense of how the taskforces can contribute to inclusion in their communities. There has been little turnover in taskforce participation with only 3 members (2 female, 1 male) withdrawing for personal reasons, these members were subsequently replaced. Taskforce meetings have been held on a weekly basis in the five different refugee camps and since the beginning of the third quarter sub-offices, that serve as a base of operation for each taskforce, have been established in each camp. It is reported that 76% of all members are between 18-30 years old and 96% between 18-45 years old. As Sahrawi authorities consider youth to be between 18-45 years old Oxfam had to stress the need to focus on younger people when meeting with local authorities, in order to secure a strong majority of taskforce participants in the age range of 18-30. The taskforces furthermore compose of 41 women and 9 men, which means that the gender representation across taskforces is unequal. However, as Sahrawi women hold far fewer positions of power than men, Oxfam highlights that majority-female taskforces will allow for female participants to lead community projects to a greater extent. The Oxfam team also views this as an opportunity to challenge the norm and they aim to open up discussions with local authorities and community leaders on gender issues. In the appraisal of the intervention, Sida raised that it is important to ensure that young women get involved and have leading positions in the taskforces, but equally important to engage young men since they are probably most likely to turn the youth frustration into concrete action. The high participation of women ensures that at least 50% of the leadership positions in the taskforce management structure can be held by women. Meanwhile, Oxfam reports that all of the taskforce members are highly motivated and have been actively involved in the training sessions and in developing concept notes, logical frameworks as well as stakeholder analyses for the upcoming community projects. Finally, to avoid a lack of trust and increase the transparency of the intervention, 15 stakeholder workshops (3 in each camp) have been held to allow for local authorities and taskforces to build up and develop a relationship of trust. During the reporting period, the taskforces have managed to develop a strong relationship with the Ministry of Cooperation. The Ministry of Cooperation have been engaged in every stage of the Musharaka project and facilitated numerous discussions with local authorities, assisted Oxfam in the search for trainers and helped to secure the sub-offices in each camp. The Sahrawi Ministries for Water/Environment and Health have also been proactive in joining in project development.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
